1.definition: the status of being qualified to assert or enforce legal rights or duties in a judicial forum because one has a sufficient and protectable interest in the outcome of a justiciable controversy and usually has suffered or is threatened with actual injury [only one who already has can argue the public interest in support of his claim ", 768 P.2d 1293 (1989)"]

2.definition: a principle requiring that a party have standing in order to justify the exercise of the court's remedial powers
